stream_context.summary: Kaze live-builds and polishes a new Wild-West themed level (working titles include "High Noon Hills", "Grandstand Badlands") for Return to Yoshi’s Island, showing off recent off-stream progress, creating cowboy NPC variants (Shy Guys, Goombas, Monty Moles, etc.), tweaking models, textures and lighting, and discussing overall project status (120 stars done, goal 140). Key technical chatter covers performance (60 FPS target, f3dx3 slowdown), shading/vertex-color tricks, and pipe model revisions.

development_findings.summary: RTYI now has 120 stars complete; scope was increased to 140 (20 more stars plus some overworld work remain).
development_findings.quote: 120 stars are finished now, but then we want 20 more stars. We need to do some overworld stuff still.

development_findings.summary: Entire Wild-West course was roughed out in ~2 weeks of focused work, making it the fastest-built level so far.
development_findings.quote: I guess I finished the whole area off stream and then also did the next area… We started on this level like 2 weeks ago and we already have the first mission done.

development_findings.summary: Level structure: a town hub, wilderness zone with oversized Western props, and a train-station sub-area housing a five-Goomba ‘shoot-out’ boss using cork guns.
development_findings.quote: This is gonna be where you're actually gonna have a shootout with… five Goombas… they're gonna be looking at you and they go this town ain't big enough for the six of us.

development_findings.summary: Other planned missions: secret saloon hideout (Snifit red-coin mine), Monty-Mole bank-robbery tunnel boss, treasure hunt with ‘X marks the spot’.
Design decision: this is the only level slated to contain multiple boss fights to fit the Western action motif.
development_findings.quote: There's gonna be a lot of boss fights in this level and it's gonna be the only level with more than one boss fight.

development_findings.summary: NPC list for the course: Cowboy Yoshis, Toads, Monty Moles, Shy Guys, Snifits, Bandits, Goombas; Kaze prototypes a cowboy Shy Guy and sets up dialog/turning AI parameters.
Triangle count optimizations are deprioritized; shading tricks and draw calls matter more for performance.
development_findings.quote: Triangle count is completely overrated… people keep telling me about triangle counts when it doesn't really matter much.

development_findings.summary: Testing shows switching to the new f3dx3 microcode drops framerate ~20 %; team stays on current renderer for now.
development_findings.quote: I imported f3dx3 and it decreased FPS by 20 %.… I'm not 100 % confident that we can use f3d x3 in the end.

development_findings.summary: New pipe models were created and iterated; lighting must remain on for proper environment mapping, leading to shader tweaks.
Uses vertex-alpha and two-cycle combiners to fake specular shine on low-poly assets while keeping performance.
development_findings.quote: Since they're both intensity textures, I can use the texture alpha and just use the combined color alpha — this way I can have three multiplications in my combiner instead of just two.

context_findings.summary: Kaze claims he avoids burnout by treating work mechanically: “I do not have a soul,” emphasizing discipline over motivation.
context_findings.quote: No, I actually never suffer from burnout… that's because I do not have a soul.

context_findings.summary: He is about to become a father and jokes about parenting, social-media rules for the child, and balancing dev life.
context_findings.quote: Who cares how the baby is named… If my child grows up to call my UVs terrible they're getting put up for adoption.

context_findings.summary: Method-acting approach: has immersed himself in cowboy movies for two weeks to capture the level’s vibe.
context_findings.quote: The last two weeks have actually been crazy. I've been watching so many cowboy movies… Everything's just cowboys in my world right now.

context_findings.summary: Philosophy: gameplay stories > blanket collectathons; level must feel purposeful and run on real hardware at 60 FPS.
context_findings.quote: I don't want that. I want to tell stories in this game… Of course this runs on real hardware — what do you think I do all the optimization for?

biobak.summary: Provided a revised pipe model with improved specular setup; active in chat troubleshooting lighting and texture issues.
biobak.quote: Alright, the pipe model? I already sent it to Mio Mike…

biobak.summary: Supplied belt texture for cowboy Shy Guy and feedback on rock textures and pipe smooth-shading.

zeina.summary: Modeled an animated dragon for an earlier level, showcased in 30 FPS playback.
zeina.quote: Zeina made the dragon, by the way. It looks so weird in high FPS.

zeina.summary: Hand-crafted new rock formations and tumbleweed assets for Western course; rocks not generated procedurally.
zeina.quote: Zeina made those manually by hand.

zeina.summary: Created new NPC head/hat assets (Goomba, Yoshi) and is actively sending them to Kaze during stream.
zeina.quote: You're making a head for the Yoshi's?… Sending to you.

key_stories.title: Building the Wild-West Course in Two Weeks
key_stories.summary: Kaze set himself a stylistic challenge: create a full Western level quickly but without sacrificing quality. Immersing in cowboy media, he blocked out three distinct areas, scripted multiple boss encounters, and hand-placed thematic props. Off-stream sprinting got the layout playable; on-stream he refined NPCs, textures, and naming.
key_stories.challenge: Deliver a fresh, story-driven course late in development while still targeting 60 FPS on real N64 hardware.
key_stories.process: Watched Western films for tone; sketched town, wilderness, train-station; reused Peach’s Fury star format; created tumbleweeds, oversized props, new pipes; scripted shoot-out scenarios.
key_stories.outcome: First mission is already functional; level runs near 60 FPS; community helps iterate names and assets; marks a new personal speed record.
key_stories.key_quote: We started on this level like 2 weeks ago and we already have the first mission done.

key_stories.title: Renderer Trade-off: f3dx3 vs Performance
key_stories.summary: Kaze tested Nintendo’s newer microcode (f3dx3) hoping for features, but frame-rate tanked by ~20 %. Decides to postpone switch until further optimization or risk assessment.
key_stories.challenge: Finding a rendering path that supports new visual tricks without breaking 60 FPS on console.
key_stories.process: Imported f3dx3, benchmarked, compared to current setup, discussed with chat.
key_stories.outcome: Stays on existing microcode; records the performance hit for future review.
key_stories.key_quote: I imported f3dx3 and it decreased FPS by 20 %.

open_questions.topic: Final course name and thematic coherence
open_questions.context: Several placeholder names floated (High Noon Hills, Grandstand Badlands, Bandit Badlands); concern over oversized props feeling ‘Worms-like’.
questions: What criteria will decide the final name?
Will surreal oversized props stay or be replaced to keep tone?
How do you balance realism vs cartoon exaggeration in level aesthetics?

open_questions.context: Western level uniquely features three bosses; rest of game mostly zero.
questions: Any risk of tonal imbalance vs other courses?
How will each boss mechanically differ to avoid repetition?
What specific benefits would justify a performance hit?
Could selective use per-object be feasible?
Is community optimizing f3dx3 for hacks?

open_questions.context: Kaze waiting for Silas to finish a new squish algorithm for character deformation.
questions: What is the technical goal of the new squish system?
How will it improve gameplay feel?

open_questions.topic: Legal considerations and potential Nintendo shutdown
open_questions.context: Chat joked about being ‘banned’ and using copyrighted assets; Kaze half-serious about risk.
questions: What precautions are in place regarding Nintendo IP?
Is there a fallback distribution strategy if C&D arrives?

open_questions.context: Project needs ~20 more stars plus overworld content.
questions: What types of stars will fill the final quota?
How will the overworld tie the story together?
